awd_abstract_narration:
The Toolik Field Station (TFS) has been a major site for research in the North American Arctic
since 1975. Much of what is known about structure and function of arctic terrestrial and aquatic
ecosystems, effects of climate change, and feedbacks to global climate has emerged from long
term, process-based ecological research at TFS. TFS-based work has resulted in significant
discoveries on adaptations of organisms to the Arctic and population-level changes in animal
and plant distributions and phenologies. Because climate is changing rapidly in the Arctic,
continuing research into mechanisms of ecosystem response and feedbacks is a high priority.
This need and ongoing interest by scientists from many disciplines in use of TFS promise a
steady demand for TFS science support in the future. TFS supports the Arctic Long-Term Ecological
Research program (LTER), projects in the Arctic Observatory Network program (AON), NASA?s
Arctic Boreal Vulnerability Experiment (ABoVE), the Earthscope Transportable Array, and is
a core site for the National Ecological Observatory Network program (NEON). TFS is a founding
partner in the EU-sponsored International Network for Terrestrial Research and Monitoring
in the Arctic (INTERACT), which links field stations around the circumpolar Arctic, and a
member of the Organization of Biological Field Stations (OBFS). At least 993 peer-reviewed
journal articles, 161 books or book chapters and 144 dissertations and theses have been published
on research based at TFS.

por.por_cntn:
Toolik Field Station (TFS) has been a major site for research in the North American Arctic since 1975. Much of what is known about structure and function of arctic terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems, effects of climate change, and feedbacks to global climate has emerged from long term, process-based ecological research at TFS. TFS-based work has resulted in significant discoveries on adaptations of organisms to the Arctic and population-level changes in animal and plant distributions and the timing of their life stages (phenologies). Because climate is changing rapidly in the Arctic, continuing research into mechanisms of ecosystem response and feedbacks is a high priority. TFS supports the Arctic Long-Term Ecological Research program (LTER), projects in the Arctic Observatory Network program (AON), and is a core site for the National Ecological Observatory Network program (NEON). TFS is a founding partner in the EU-sponsored International Network for Terrestrial Research and Monitoring in the Arctic (INTERACT), which links field stations around the circumpolar Arctic, and a member of the Organization of Biological Field Stations (OBFS). More than 1600 peer-reviewed journal articles (70 in high impact journals, with >22,000 combined citations), 198 books or book chapters, and 235 dissertations and theses have been published on research based at TFS.

 

TFS is operated and managed by the Institute of Arctic Biology, University of Alaska Fairbanks with cooperative agreement support from the National Science Foundation (NSF). Under this award, our objective was to provide excellent logistical and research support, scientific services, and year-round access to enable science users of TFS to achieve sophisticated research under safe conditions and maximize use of their grant dollars for research. TFS management maintained excellent communication with scientists by seeking feedback and making decisions transparently. Excellent logistical support was provided, including utilities, housing, meals, laboratory space, safety training and management. Core research support was maintained and improved in GIS services, UAS imagery, baseline environmental monitoring, remote access, common-use scientific equipment, and building/repairing field gear and instruments. Two All Scientists’ Meetings & Workshops were held to promote collaboration, assess current science support services, and recommend future services. Research and educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students were offered, and outreach was facilitated for journalists, K-12 students and teachers, and the public.

 

The COVID-19 pandemic posed a significant challenge to our operations, but we kept TFS operational and overcame many challenges of the evolving pandemic. TFS was forced to close to researchers for several months in 2020. We offered remote access to assist researchers who could not come in person, by collecting data for them according to their protocols. This service continues to be popular. When we re-opened, we implemented quarantine and testing protocols in 2020-2022, which prevented COVID-19 at TFS. In 2023, we switched to a testing only protocol, and though some COVID cases occurred, we had no large outbreaks at TFS.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Intellectual merit in managing TFS resulted from employing best practices in field station management, informed by participation in INTERACT and OBFS. TFS management was responsive to science users and sought their input, through workshops, surveys, and advisory committees. TFS management closed the communication loop with scientists and NSF. Intellectual merit also resulted from accomplishments of the productive scientists working at TFS, whose work is internationally recognized, and whose success was supported by TFS services. During this award, TFS supported between 1524 (in 2020) and 9934 (in 2023) user days for scientists and contractors, for an average of 7130 user days (one person at TFS for one day = one userday). Funding for research came predominantly (84% average) from NSF, with some projects funded by NASA, DOE, and the State of Alaska. TFS promoted international collaboration by supporting in-person access for 5 European research projects and remote access for 11 European projects, funded by INTERACT. TFS also supported two projects from Italy and Poland funded by their national research agencies.

 

Broader Impacts:

Broader impacts included enhancing research infrastructure by providing baseline environmental monitoring data, maps, UAS imagery, and spatial analyses that create context for research based at TFS; remote access; and support for undergraduate and graduate student education. Physical infrastructure was improved by obtaining a medical facility and a shower facility, funded by NSF. Another broader impact was promoting safe and inclusive fieldwork. Our Code of Conduct (which covers sexual harassment) and mandatory on-line training policy were updated, a climate survey was implemented, and we worked to create a community of respect through dialog and education. Finally, field experiences promote discovery-based learning and personal transformation, and we created opportunities for students and faculty to form new collaborations by hosting field classes and research projects. Many scientists have based their careers around work at TFS and return year after year. Research conducted at TFS in this period addressed research questions relevant for the future of humanity in a changing environment.
